Authors: Paul E Marek, Jason E Bond
Title:
A reassessment of apheloriine millipede phylogeny: additional
taxa, Bayesian inference, and direct optimization (Polydesmida:
Xystodesmidae)
Abstract:
Millipedes in the tribe Apheloriini occur throughout the
eastern United States, predominately in the deciduous forests of the
Appalachian Mountains. Herein we present a reassessment of apheloriine
millipede phylogeny using mitochondrial DNA sequences and an additional
29 exemplar taxa (including 15 undescribed species and all of the
species in the genus Brachoria, except one). In this study, first
we check the results of the previous phylogeny of the tribe (Marek and
Bond, 2006) with different alignment and phylogenetic techniques (direct
optimization and maximum likelihood), and second reconstruct a new
phylogeny evaluating it in the same way with Bayesian, maximum
likelihood, and direct optimization. Using this updated and expanded
phylogeny, we tested historical classifications with Bayes factor and
Shimodaira-Hasegawa hypothesis testing, consistently finding very strong
evidence against their implied phylogenetic hypotheses. Lastly, using
the new phylogeny as a foundation, we make taxonomic modifications and
provide an updated species-list of Apheloriini (104 species/17
genera).
